THE NEWS-LETTER.

opportunities thus gained to help them. They
have exceptional opportunities for studying
the conditions by which they are surrounded,
and acquire an influence over their neighbors
which it would be impossible to gain in any
other way.
Work of this kind was begun in Baltimore
in 1893, when Rev. Edward A. Lawrence, pastor of the First Congregational Church, and
Mr. E. D. Thomson, of the University, went
to live in Baltimore's tenement section on Parkin street. Mr. Lawrence died soon after, and
an association, of which the Hopkins Y. M. C.
A. is a member, determined to carry on the
work in his name. This organization is known
as the Lawrence Memorial Association, and
the house which it now owns is called "Lawrence House." Students of the Woman's College and the young people of the First Congregational and Harlem Avenue Christian
Churches are also represented in its management.
In this house work for the improvement of
the boys and girls of the neighborhood is carried on. It is not a religious institution, and
no religious services are held. Educational
classes, manual training and amusements are
provided for the boys. There are work
benches where they learn to use carpenters'
,tools, and skilled wood-workers teach them
carving., The instruction is all practical, and
interesting games and amusements are used
judiciously. On certain days the house is
open for girls. Lessons in cooking strike at
the root of false economy in the household,
one of the greatest causes of poverty. In the
sewing classes girls learn to cut and finish
their own garments, and some are taught to
embroider. All these efforts, directed at the
most impressionable class in the community,
are wonderfully successful. More boys and
girls apply for admission than can be accommodated.
The house is not only a means of carrying
on the classes just mentioned, but serves also
as a model household. The children arc
taught how to sweep and dust, make beds, and

manage the details of housekeeping. The
whole building is designed as an object lesson.
Of late the work has been reaching out in
both directions. There is a kindergarten for
the little ones, and a savings bank that has
been of much service to the boys will be extended for the use of their elders. Other efforts in behalf of the adults of the neighborhood are contemplated.
At present no students lodge in the house.
It is being found, generally, in the settlement
work, that most students can work more effectively by visiting the houses at regular
hours, leaving others to give their whole time
to the field.
Among the Hopkins students now engaged
at Lawrence House are Messrs. H. B. Foster,
J. S. Chamberlain, N. A. Kent and H. A.
Hamilton, of the graduate departments, and
Messrs. Rous, Schermerhorn and J. G. Griffin,
from the undergraduates.
THE FIRST MUSICALE.
The series of entertainments to be given this
year by the Hopkins Musical Association was
begun by a delightful concert in McCoy Hall,
on December 10. President Gilman welcomed
the guests of the association in a few graceful
words at the beginning of the programme.
The music was in charge of Mr. Edward
Heimendahl, who played as the first number
a violin arioso by Julius Reitz, in which he
was accompanied on the organ by Mr. G.
Wright Nicols. He played with careful attention to phrasing, being hampered somewhat by an unresponsive accompaniment.
This, however, only ac.cented his control over
the instrument and his perfect familiarity with
,the composer. Two trios for sopranos were
well sung by the Misses Brown, Carey and
Pagon. The three voices harmonized beautifully, and showed much attention to precision
in time and expression. The choice of the
Chopin fantasy for piano, played by Miss Hermine Lenders, was possibly injudicious, as it
lacks sustained interest. The performance

THE NEWS-LETTER.
was conscientious, and Miss Leuders' technique unquestioned. Dr. Baker sang four
.,songs by McDowell, artistic little pieces which
were , well interpreted, though the singer
seemed not to be in his best form. The last
selection, a piano quintet by Schumann, was
quite successful, considering the importance of
the work and the limited time available for rehearsals. The performers were Miss Leuders,
Messrs. Heimendahl, Moses, Siemann, and
Fuerthermaier.

A CLASS ON CURRENT TOPICS.

Dr. J. H. Hollander, of the Department of
Historical and Political Science, recently revived an interesting course of study on topics
of current interest in American politics. He
takes the Congressional Record and other reports of public proceedings in Washington,
and discourses on the more important matters
horn week to week, with a class of advanced
students. Last year a deep interest was awakened among the students by a similar course,
and the present conference should be even
more successful, in view of the great interest
now existing in American colonial and international questions. No better illustration
could be desired of the true significance of
Freeman's motto, "History is past politics, and
politics present history." Hopkins students
should be abreast of the age in which they are
to live and work.

The way the Hopkins men rooted at the St.
John's football game, and, in fact, at all our
games last fall, was a disgrace. In the first
place, they paid no attention to grouping themselves properly. It is impossible for a crowd

Conditions at Hopkins differ from those
found in mostcolleges in that the collegiate and
post-graduate departments are of about the
same size. For this reason outsiders who know
only the one or the other frequently get their
ideas of our college life somewhat mixed. Visitors who are familiar with the advanced department alone, often embarrass under-graduates by asking what college they are from,and
Baltimoreans who get their ideas of us from
the daily press wrongfully attribute to the
graduates the innocent diversions of their juniors. If the incipient Ph. D.'s will unbend a
little, and the under-graduates take on some
added dignity, we shall reach the golden mean
that will make our student-body homogeneous.

After the Christmas vacation, the season of
class banquets will soon be upon us. The
banqueters will do well to remember that the
object of these gatherings is good-fellowship.
The food and drink are incidental features that
contribute to that end. A banquet should
bring the men closer together and cement the
friendships that have been forming in classroom and gym. For this purpose the toasts
and responses are more important than they
are sometimes considered. A certain degree
of dignity and decorum are essential, even at a
freshman banquet. A risque story that seems
unobjectionable in a group of two or three,
may be in very bad taste when delivered to a
larger company. Over-abundant enthusiasm
that disregards the rights of others soon becomes a nuisance.

It seems quite the fashion these late years
for the Freshmen to trounce the Juniors in
any of the little class altercations that arise.
The "old student," who has watched the course
of undergraduate life, finds a plausible explanation of this phenomenon in the burning enthusiasm of the new man, and the flickering
flame of the Junior. The preparatory years of
the Freshman were inspirited with the lore of
green. paint, pot socials and kindred festivities.
He comes into the arena
e., the cage) with
his sleeves rolled up and "light in his eye." He
comes in great numbers. The Junior the
while has had his "baptism of fire." The
glory of the pot social is dimmed by distance,
or the memory of a sore head. He has lost
his itching for the fray. With depleted ranks,
he is routed. And so, as a consequence, the
benevolent intention of hazing is lost, unless
the humbling of the Junior is as much a service as the salting of the fresh.
Most of us, certainly the Seniors, are more
concerned with the budding hopes of the New
Year than with the ashes of the Old. But 1898
has had many things to make it memorable in
Hopkins annals. Was not the completion of
the new gymnasium and the long dreamed of
cage enough? But to this was added a gorgeous series of athletic triumphs—the winning
of the lacrosse championship, the relay at the
University of Pennsylvania, first and brilliant
honors in the Maryland Intercollegiate Association and the Maryland Athletic Union, together with that smart entrance into the American Intercollegiate games at Berkely Oval.
But 1898 was not content with athletic victories: the Musical Association, and the College
Congress, with its public prize debate, came as
brand-new features of our University life. The
appropriation from the State, the inauguration
of the Teachers' Lectures—how significant!
And not least of all was witnessed the passing
of hazing! You were good to us,'98. Though
they have trundled you off a worn-out,

5

broken-down old year, and have given your
place to a stripling young upstart, your memory will live on in the heart of Hopkins.

MR. WIGHT'S RADIOGRAPHS.

A highly interesting exhibit of radiographs
is hung in McCoy Hall, the work of Mr. Carol
Wight, 19oo, associated with his brother, Dr.
T. Sherman Wight. A novel method was employed. The radiographs exhibited are direct
prints on ordinary bromide paper. Advantage
is taken of the flexibility of the paper to secure
close contact with the part to be radiographed,
insuring sharper delineation. In one example, an inflexible necrosed elbow-joint, bent at
right angles, was photographed by bending the
sensitive paper round the "back" of the joint,
and the resulting picture shows the projection
of two perpendicular planes.
The most important feature of the method
used by Mr. Wight over the ordinary method,
is that more "opaque" parts are light in the resulting print, those more permeable, dark. So
detail is not lost in shadows. In a radiograph
of the hand, the sesimoid bones, the nails, epipyses and the overlapping of flesh between the
fingers is shown clearly and sharply. In certain cases diseased tissue has been successfully
detected. The collection includes radiographs
of the shoulder, knee joint, fractures of the fore
arm and several of rabbits.

ATH LETICS.

THE JUNIOR-FRESHMEN FOOTBALL GAME.

The regular football season at the University
came to an end with our game at St. John's
College, on November 16th. The Junior and
'Freshman classes decided, however, to extend
the season a little, and to put their rivalry to a
practical test in a struggle at Electric Park.
The game took place on Wednesday, December 7th. Both teams were confident, the
Juniors in their weight, and the Freshmen in
their team work. On each side were some of
the best players in the undergraduate department. The Juniors, however, were over-confident, and did not play with as much vim as
they would otherwise have shown. The
Freshmen played their best, and, though outweighed, held their opponents; and the game
resulted in a draw.
Bull's long run placed I90I's goal in extreme danger at one time, but the score was
prevented by Constantine, who followed him
clear down the field, and threw him on the tenyard line. Glaser made a good run just before
the game ended. These runs, with Griffin's
beautiful tackle of Wirt in the first half, were
the best plays. The backs on both sides also
distinguished themselves.
Griffin kicked off, and, after the ball was put
into play, the Juniors made a few gains, and
then fumbled. The ball went over, and Griffin
punted to I9oo's fifteen-yard line. After some
gains of five and three yards by Sayler and
Griffin, the Juniors got the ball, and Wirt and
Bull went around the ends and through the
line for ten yards and three yards, respectively.
Then came Bull's long run and his tackle by
Constantine and Sayler on the ten-yard line.
The Juniors, however, were unable to carry
the ball over the goal line.
The second half was merely a repetition of
the first. The Juniors were crippled, and their
team work was poor; while the playing of the
Freshmen improved. The game ended with
the score o to o.

The game was interesting not only as an opportunity to measure the strength of the two
classes, which seem to be quite evenly matched,
but also as an indication of the prospect for the
next year's 'Varsity team. Bruton, W. L.
Smith, Whitman, Sayler, and Griffin, all of
whom were "subs" this season, are the most
promising candidates.

THE CANC. RUSH.

Ever since the opening of the University
this year, the Freshman and the Junior classes
have been spoiling for a chance to measure
strength with each other.
They were prevented from hazing and having "pot-socials" by a faculty decree issued
last year, which prohibited such sport.
At last a way was discovered. It was suggested to have a football game between teams
from the two classes. The game was held, but
unfortunately (for some) neither side scored,
and the question still remained unanswered,
"Which is the stronger class?"
This question was given much thought all
the way from the football grounds back to the
Gymnasium, and likewise much discussion ensued. By the time each team and their classmates reached the "Gym." it was just about
ready to prove the other class inferior; but
there could be no "pot-socialing," so what was
to be done? Soon it was suggested that there
be a cane rush. Everyone consented, so without much delay the representatives of the two
classes were out in the Cage, Freshmen at one

THE NEWS-LETTER.
end and Juniors at the other. The Freshmen
had a slight advantage over the Juniors, in
having more men present. It was too late,
however, to have an equal representation from
each class, so they contested unequally.
The cane was thrown up in the middle of the
Cage, and then the fun began. They tugged
and pushed and pulled and wrestled, until the
signal was given to stop.
The hands on the stick were then counted,
and the result was: Freshmen, 13 hands; Juniors, 10 hands.
This was quite a blow to the Juniors, who
declared that they would have won in an equal
contest, while the Freshmen went away in
great glee.

MUSCULAR UNDERGRADUATES.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
UNIVERSITY NEWS.

President Gilman and Dr. Remsen were
guests at the banquet of the Civil Service Reform Association, last Friday night.
Last Saturday evening a class in Social Science, under the direction of Dr. Jeffrey Brackett, visited a number of cheap lodging houses
in the lower sections of the city.
At a class-meeting last week the seniors determined to hold their banquet about the first
of February. Mr. Henry C. Downs was
elected an associate editor of the Hullabaloo, in
the place of Mr. Morgan, who resigned.
Mr. Philip Sidney Morgan, of the senior
class, has been compelled by the failure of his
eyes to give up his work at the University for
this year. Mr. Morgan will spend some
months roughing it on a Western ranch, and
hopes to take up the work again next fall.
On Wednesday last, Dr. Hollander's class
in Economics listened to a short talk on the
subject by M. Siegfried, of Paris, who is in
America for the purpose of carrying on study
which he is making of the progress of the Science of Economics in various countries of the
world.
An interesting experiment was conducted
in the biological laboratory last week to learn
the difference between natural sleep and that
due to hypnotic influence. Mr. P. S. Morgan,
who has had considerable success as an amateur, was the hypnotist.
During the Christmas vacation a number of
meetings of interest to Hopkins students will
be held at various universities. The American
Society of Naturalists, together with several
other societies grouped about it, will meet at

Columbia. The American Folk-lore Society
will also convene there. At the University of
Virginia, a meeting of the Modern Language
Association is to be held, and it will be attended by a number of men from here. Among
the papers read by these will be one by Dr. R.
•H. Wilson, one by Dr. J. S. Baker, and another by Dr. W. Stuart Symington, of Amherst, who took his Ph. D. here several years
ago.
The Maryland Geological Survey is making
an unusually interesting exhibition in the cases
in the first floor corridor of McCoy Hall. It
consists of several fine photographs of the
Maryland quarrying industries and of Maryland scenery, together with the latest maps of
the Survey. There are also photomicrographs and lithographic reproductions of
Maryland building stones. This last work
was done by the Heliotpye Printing Co., of
Boston, and is exceptionally clear and beautiful. The exhibit appears as illustrations in the
publications of the Survey.
EXCHANOES.

The students at Princeton have abolished
hazing—again. Their annual attack of virtue
usually occurs about this time.
The President of Dartmouth has utterly
abolished the "Rho Kappa Tau" fraternity, a
time-honored institution whose sign was a
bloody tomahawk, and whose exclusive object
was attending to conspicuous freshmen.
Maryland Agricultural College is taking an
enforced vacation on account of an epidemic of
diphtheria.
Harvard and Williams have each been endowed with a fund yielding about $5oo annually, to be awarded to the senior writing the
best essay on an economic subject.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

opportunities thus gained to help them. They
have exceptional opportunities for studying
the conditions by which they are surrounded,
and acquire an influence over their neighbors
which it would be impossible to gain in any
other way.
Work of this kind was begun in Baltimore
in 1893, when Rev. Edward A. Lawrence, pastor of the First Congregational Church, and
Mr. E. D. Thomson, of the University, went
to live in Baltimore's tenement section on Parkin street. Mr. Lawrence died soon after, and
an association, of which the Hopkins Y. M. C.
A. is a member, determined to carry on the
work in his name. This organization is known
as the Lawrence Memorial Association, and
the house which it now owns is called "Lawrence House." Students of the Woman's College and the young people of the First Congregational and Harlem Avenue Christian
Churches are also represented in its management.
In this house work for the improvement of
the boys and girls of the neighborhood is carried on. It is not a religious institution, and
no religious services are held. Educational
classes, manual training and amusements are
provided for the boys. There are work
benches where they learn to use carpenters'
,tools, and skilled wood-workers teach them
carving., The instruction is all practical, and
interesting games and amusements are used
judiciously. On certain days the house is
open for girls. Lessons in cooking strike at
the root of false economy in the household,
one of the greatest causes of poverty. In the
sewing classes girls learn to cut and finish
their own garments, and some are taught to
embroider. All these efforts, directed at the
most impressionable class in the community,
are wonderfully successful. More boys and
girls apply for admission than can be accommodated.
The house is not only a means of carrying
on the classes just mentioned, but serves also
as a model household. The children arc
taught how to sweep and dust, make beds, and

manage the details of housekeeping. The
whole building is designed as an object lesson.
Of late the work has been reaching out in
both directions. There is a kindergarten for
the little ones, and a savings bank that has
been of much service to the boys will be extended for the use of their elders. Other efforts in behalf of the adults of the neighborhood are contemplated.
At present no students lodge in the house.
It is being found, generally, in the settlement
work, that most students can work more effectively by visiting the houses at regular
hours, leaving others to give their whole time
to the field.
Among the Hopkins students now engaged
at Lawrence House are Messrs. H. B. Foster,
J. S. Chamberlain, N. A. Kent and H. A.
Hamilton, of the graduate departments, and
Messrs. Rous, Schermerhorn and J. G. Griffin,
from the undergraduates.
THE FIRST MUSICALE.
The series of entertainments to be given this
year by the Hopkins Musical Association was
begun by a delightful concert in McCoy Hall,
on December 10. President Gilman welcomed
the guests of the association in a few graceful
words at the beginning of the programme.
The music was in charge of Mr. Edward
Heimendahl, who played as the first number
a violin arioso by Julius Reitz, in which he
was accompanied on the organ by Mr. G.
Wright Nicols. He played with careful attention to phrasing, being hampered somewhat by an unresponsive accompaniment.
This, however, only ac.cented his control over
the instrument and his perfect familiarity with
,the composer. Two trios for sopranos were
well sung by the Misses Brown, Carey and
Pagon. The three voices harmonized beautifully, and showed much attention to precision
in time and expression. The choice of the
Chopin fantasy for piano, played by Miss Hermine Lenders, was possibly injudicious, as it

A CLASS ON CURRENT TOPICS.

Dr. J. H. Hollander, of the Department of
Historical and Political Science, recently revived an interesting course of study on topics
of current interest in American politics. He
takes the Congressional Record and other reports of public proceedings in Washington,
and discourses on the more important matters
horn week to week, with a class of advanced
students. Last year a deep interest was awakened among the students by a similar course,
and the present conference should be even
more successful, in view of the great interest
now existing in American colonial and international questions. No better illustration
could be desired of the true significance of
Freeman's motto, "History is past politics, and
politics present history." Hopkins students
should be abreast of the age in which they are
to live and work.

Conditions at Hopkins differ from those
found in mostcolleges in that the collegiate and
post-graduate departments are of about the
same size. For this reason outsiders who know
only the one or the other frequently get their
ideas of our college life somewhat mixed. Visitors who are familiar with the advanced department alone, often embarrass under-graduates by asking what college they are from,and
Baltimoreans who get their ideas of us from
the daily press wrongfully attribute to the
graduates the innocent diversions of their juniors. If the incipient Ph. D.'s will unbend a
little, and the under-graduates take on some
added dignity, we shall reach the golden mean
that will make our student-body homogeneous.

After the Christmas vacation, the season of
class banquets will soon be upon us. The
banqueters will do well to remember that the

The food and drink are incidental features that
contribute to that end. A banquet should
bring the men closer together and cement the
friendships that have been forming in classroom and gym. For this purpose the toasts
and responses are more important than they
are sometimes considered. A certain degree
of dignity and decorum are essential, even at a
freshman banquet. A risque story that seems
unobjectionable in a group of two or three,
may be in very bad taste when delivered to a
larger company. Over-abundant enthusiasm
that disregards the rights of others soon becomes a nuisance.

It seems quite the fashion these late years
for the Freshmen to trounce the Juniors in
any of the little class altercations that arise.
The "old student," who has watched the course
of undergraduate life, finds a plausible explanation of this phenomenon in the burning enthusiasm of the new man, and the flickering
flame of the Junior. The preparatory years of
the Freshman were inspirited with the lore of
green. paint, pot socials and kindred festivities.
He comes into the arena
e., the cage) with
his sleeves rolled up and "light in his eye." He
comes in great numbers. The Junior the
while has had his "baptism of fire." The
glory of the pot social is dimmed by distance,
or the memory of a sore head. He has lost
his itching for the fray. With depleted ranks,
he is routed. And so, as a consequence, the
benevolent intention of hazing is lost, unless
the humbling of the Junior is as much a service as the salting of the fresh.
Most of us, certainly the Seniors, are more
concerned with the budding hopes of the New
Year than with the ashes of the Old. But 1898
has had many things to make it memorable in
Hopkins annals. Was not the completion of
the new gymnasium and the long dreamed of
cage enough? But to this was added a gorgeous series of athletic triumphs—the winning
of the lacrosse championship, the relay at the
University of Pennsylvania, first and brilliant
honors in the Maryland Intercollegiate Association and the Maryland Athletic Union, together with that smart entrance into the American Intercollegiate games at Berkely Oval.
But 1898 was not content with athletic victories: the Musical Association, and the College
Congress, with its public prize debate, came as
brand-new features of our University life. The
appropriation from the State, the inauguration
of the Teachers' Lectures—how significant!
And not least of all was witnessed the passing
of hazing! You were good to us,'98. Though
they have trundled you off a worn-out,

5

broken-down old year, and have given your
place to a stripling young upstart, your memory will live on in the heart of Hopkins.

MR. WIGHT'S RADIOGRAPHS.

A highly interesting exhibit of radiographs
is hung in McCoy Hall, the work of Mr. Carol
Wight, 19oo, associated with his brother, Dr.
T. Sherman Wight. A novel method was employed. The radiographs exhibited are direct
prints on ordinary bromide paper. Advantage
is taken of the flexibility of the paper to secure
close contact with the part to be radiographed,
insuring sharper delineation. In one example, an inflexible necrosed elbow-joint, bent at
right angles, was photographed by bending the
sensitive paper round the "back" of the joint,
and the resulting picture shows the projection
of two perpendicular planes.
The most important feature of the method
used by Mr. Wight over the ordinary method,
is that more "opaque" parts are light in the resulting print, those more permeable, dark. So
detail is not lost in shadows. In a radiograph
of the hand, the sesimoid bones, the nails, epipyses and the overlapping of flesh between the
fingers is shown clearly and sharply. In certain cases diseased tissue has been successfully
detected. The collection includes radiographs
of the shoulder, knee joint, fractures of the fore
arm and several of rabbits.

ATH LETICS.

THE JUNIOR-FRESHMEN FOOTBALL GAME.

The regular football season at the University
came to an end with our game at St. John's
College, on November 16th. The Junior and
'Freshman classes decided, however, to extend
the season a little, and to put their rivalry to a
practical test in a struggle at Electric Park.
The game took place on Wednesday, December 7th. Both teams were confident, the
Juniors in their weight, and the Freshmen in
their team work. On each side were some of
the best players in the undergraduate department. The Juniors, however, were over-confident, and did not play with as much vim as
they would otherwise have shown. The
Freshmen played their best, and, though outweighed, held their opponents; and the game
resulted in a draw.
Bull's long run placed I90I's goal in extreme danger at one time, but the score was
prevented by Constantine, who followed him
clear down the field, and threw him on the tenyard line. Glaser made a good run just before
the game ended. These runs, with Griffin's
beautiful tackle of Wirt in the first half, were
the best plays. The backs on both sides also
distinguished themselves.
Griffin kicked off, and, after the ball was put
into play, the Juniors made a few gains, and
then fumbled. The ball went over, and Griffin
punted to I9oo's fifteen-yard line. After some
gains of five and three yards by Sayler and
Griffin, the Juniors got the ball, and Wirt and
Bull went around the ends and through the
line for ten yards and three yards, respectively.
Then came Bull's long run and his tackle by
Constantine and Sayler on the ten-yard line.
The Juniors, however, were unable to carry
the ball over the goal line.
The second half was merely a repetition of
the first. The Juniors were crippled, and their
team work was poor; while the playing of the
Freshmen improved. The game ended with
the score o to o.

The game was interesting not only as an opportunity to measure the strength of the two
classes, which seem to be quite evenly matched,
but also as an indication of the prospect for the
next year's 'Varsity team. Bruton, W. L.
Smith, Whitman, Sayler, and Griffin, all of
whom were "subs" this season, are the most
promising candidates.

THE CANC. RUSH.

Ever since the opening of the University
this year, the Freshman and the Junior classes
have been spoiling for a chance to measure
strength with each other.
They were prevented from hazing and having "pot-socials" by a faculty decree issued
last year, which prohibited such sport.
At last a way was discovered. It was suggested to have a football game between teams
from the two classes. The game was held, but
unfortunately (for some) neither side scored,
and the question still remained unanswered,
"Which is the stronger class?"
This question was given much thought all
the way from the football grounds back to the
Gymnasium, and likewise much discussion ensued. By the time each team and their classmates reached the "Gym." it was just about
ready to prove the other class inferior; but
there could be no "pot-socialing," so what was
to be done? Soon it was suggested that there
be a cane rush. Everyone consented, so without much delay the representatives of the two
classes were out in the Cage, Freshmen at one

THE NEWS-LETTER.
end and Juniors at the other. The Freshmen
had a slight advantage over the Juniors, in
having more men present. It was too late,
however, to have an equal representation from
each class, so they contested unequally.
The cane was thrown up in the middle of the
Cage, and then the fun began. They tugged
and pushed and pulled and wrestled, until the
signal was given to stop.
The hands on the stick were then counted,
and the result was: Freshmen, 13 hands; Juniors, 10 hands.
This was quite a blow to the Juniors, who
declared that they would have won in an equal
contest, while the Freshmen went away in
great glee.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
UNIVERSITY NEWS.

President Gilman and Dr. Remsen were
guests at the banquet of the Civil Service Reform Association, last Friday night.
Last Saturday evening a class in Social Science, under the direction of Dr. Jeffrey Brackett, visited a number of cheap lodging houses
in the lower sections of the city.
At a class-meeting last week the seniors determined to hold their banquet about the first
of February. Mr. Henry C. Downs was
elected an associate editor of the Hullabaloo, in
the place of Mr. Morgan, who resigned.
Mr. Philip Sidney Morgan, of the senior
class, has been compelled by the failure of his
eyes to give up his work at the University for
this year. Mr. Morgan will spend some
months roughing it on a Western ranch, and
hopes to take up the work again next fall.
On Wednesday last, Dr. Hollander's class
in Economics listened to a short talk on the
subject by M. Siegfried, of Paris, who is in
America for the purpose of carrying on study
which he is making of the progress of the Science of Economics in various countries of the
world.
An interesting experiment was conducted
in the biological laboratory last week to learn
the difference between natural sleep and that
due to hypnotic influence. Mr. P. S. Morgan,
who has had considerable success as an amateur, was the hypnotist.
During the Christmas vacation a number of
meetings of interest to Hopkins students will
be held at various universities. The American
Society of Naturalists, together with several
other societies grouped about it, will meet at

Columbia. The American Folk-lore Society
will also convene there. At the University of
Virginia, a meeting of the Modern Language
Association is to be held, and it will be attended by a number of men from here. Among
the papers read by these will be one by Dr. R.
•H. Wilson, one by Dr. J. S. Baker, and another by Dr. W. Stuart Symington, of Amherst, who took his Ph. D. here several years
ago.
The Maryland Geological Survey is making
an unusually interesting exhibition in the cases
in the first floor corridor of McCoy Hall. It
consists of several fine photographs of the
Maryland quarrying industries and of Maryland scenery, together with the latest maps of
the Survey. There are also photomicrographs and lithographic reproductions of
Maryland building stones. This last work
was done by the Heliotpye Printing Co., of
Boston, and is exceptionally clear and beautiful. The exhibit appears as illustrations in the
publications of the Survey.
EXCHANOES.

The students at Princeton have abolished
hazing—again. Their annual attack of virtue
usually occurs about this time.
The President of Dartmouth has utterly
abolished the "Rho Kappa Tau" fraternity, a
time-honored institution whose sign was a
bloody tomahawk, and whose exclusive object
was attending to conspicuous freshmen.
Maryland Agricultural College is taking an
enforced vacation on account of an epidemic of
diphtheria.
Harvard and Williams have each been endowed with a fund yielding about $5oo annually, to be awarded to the senior writing the
best essay on an economic subject.
